column3: Referring to an act committed by an opponent in negative terms while referring to the same act committed by the arguer or supporters in favorable terms.
column4: Using language and punctuation in a way that a statement can have multiple interpretations, so it's not really clear what is meant.
column5: Confusing figurative language with literal language

column1: Automatically rejecting a claim just because it's traditional is...
A slippery-slope pattern of argument is fallacious when...
column3: There is good reason to think that doing one action will inevitably lead to another undesirable action
column4: There are only two possible results
column5: There is no good reason to think that doing one action will inevitably lead to another undesirable action

column1: Which of the following best describes the fallacy of special pleading?
column2: Reasoning that ideas presented in an appealing manner are correct, regardless of the content of the message.
column3: Using language and punctuation in a way that a statement can have multiple interpretations, so it's not really clear what is meant.
column4: Confusing figurative language with literal language.
column5: Referring to an act committed by an opponent in negative terms while referring to the same act committed by the arguer or supporters in favorable terms

column1: Whether someone is hypocritical regarding her claims is...
column3: Evidence that the claims are false
column4: Irrelevant to the truth of the claims

column1: If someone says if you do something it will lead to extreme consequences, but doesn't provide you with any evidence of a cause and effect relationship between your act and those consequences, that person has probably committed which of the following fallacies?
The concomitant variation fallacy is
column2: attributing the cause of an event to a single cause when the cause is more complicated
column3: arguing that since two events happened at the same time, one event must have caused the other
column4: arguing that since one event preceded another event it must have caused the second event
column5: drawing a conclusion based on sign reasoning when there is not really a direct relationship between the alleged sign and the subject of the conclusion

column1: " _Ad novitatem_ " is a specific kind of fallacy of
Rejecting a claim by criticizing the person who makes it rather than the claim itself is known as the fallacy of...
Which of the following best describes the fallacy of amphiboly?
column2: Using emotionally charged languages to create an impression about the subject of a claim, without making an argument that the language fits the subject.
column3: Referring to an act committed by an opponent in negative terms while referring to the same act committed by the arguer or supporters in favorable terms.
column4: Using grammar and punctuation in a way that a statement may have multiple interpretations, so it's not really clear what is meant.
column5: Changing the meaning of a word or phrase from one part of the argument to another.

column1: When someone uses grammar or punctuation in a way that makes a statement have more than one possible interpretation, that person may have committed which of the following fallacies?
Telling people that they haven't been harmed because there is something they should be thankful for commits which of the following fallacies?
